channel.title: BUscience
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUscience, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Scientists unveil new insights into air pollution formation
item.description: Researchers have made a groundbreaking discovery in understanding how air pollution forms at the molecular level. Their investigation sheds light on t...

item.title: Pesticides affect the health of wild bees, important plant pollinators
item.description: Native wild bees native play a critical role in ecosystems, pollinating countless plant species, including agricultural crops. Pollination from wild a...

item.title: Snakes don't go with their gut, they regenerate it
item.description: Humans aren't capable of regrowing limbs like some salamanders or full organs like some snails and zebrafish, but we do renew some of our cells, inclu...

item.title: Plant guard cells can count environmental stimuli
item.description: Plants adapt their water consumption to environmental conditions by counting and calculating environmental stimuli with their guard cells.

item.title: Surfing atmospheric waves with tiny satellites
item.description: A U.S. National Science Foundation-supported team is designing and building three identical CubeSats, or shoebox-sized satellites, to study space weat...

item.title: Rare fossils of extinct elephant document the earliest known instance of butchery in India
item.description: Scientists have discovered the earliest evidence of animal butchery by humans in India.

item.title: Plant CO2 uptake rises by nearly one third in new global estimates
item.description: Plants the world over are absorbing about 31% more carbon dioxide than previously thought, according to a new assessment. The research is expected to ...

item.title: Creating a simplified form of life
item.description: How can lifeless molecules come together to form a living cell?

item.title: Dead coral skeletons left by bleaching events hinder reef recovery
